title: Bristol and Bath Railway Path Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Oli Allen / Bristol-Bath Railway Path
images.caption: On the Avon Valley railway, with Oldland Common station just behind the bridge.

images.title: Martyn Pattison / Bristol and Bath railway path crossing the river Avon.
images.caption: Bristol and Bath railway path crossing the river Avon.

images.title: Pierre Terre / River Avon, Kelston Park Railway Bridge
images.caption: River Avon, Kelston Park Railway Bridge. Rowers heading up against the current past the former railway bridge.

images.title: Rwendland, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Kelston Park,from Seven Acre Wood near Newton St Loe, across the River Avon valley. The bridge over the river carries the Bristol and Bath Railway Path.

images.title: Graham D / The Bristol and Bath Railway Path through a park in Newtown
images.caption: View of the surfaced path through a park in Newtown. Looking north east in the direction of Easton, this photo was taken near the start of the trail.

images.title: Linda Bailey / Bristol to Bath Cycle Path
images.caption: Looking down on the Bristol to Bath cycle path from above. The trail was the first cycle route created by Sustrans. Taken looking down from the bridge on Devon Road in Easton.

images.title: Nigel Thompson / Oldland Common railway station, Gloucestershire
images.caption: Oldland Common railway station, Gloucestershire. Opened in 1935 by the London Midland & Scottish Railway on the line from Bristol to Bath Green Park via Mangotsfield, this station closed to passengers in 1966. It was rebuilt (slightly further away from the camera position) in 1992 as part of what is now the heritage Avon Valley Railway. View north east towards Warmley and Mangotsfield.

images.title: don cload / Warmley Station
images.caption: Warmley Station. The station office is now a cafe.

description: This lovely cycle or walk takes you along a disused railway line with its series of charming stations. Starting in the historic city of Bristol you will pass through Staple Hill, Mangotsfield and then Warmley where the station platform contains a cafe - perfect for a stop for refreshments. The route then takes you along the Avon Valley Railway and past Bitton railway station which also has a cafe. The final delightful section takes you along the River Avon and into the historic city of Bath. To extend the ride you can pick up the Kennet and Avon Canal in Bath. There's more easy cycling to be enjoyed along the flat towpath here. See the Bristol Cycle Routes page for more cycling ideas in and around the city.
